column14: Plaque Info
column16: Plaque More Info

column14: Emmeline Pankhurst (1858-1928) Dame Christabel Pankhurst (1880-1958) Campaigners for Women's Suffrage lived here
column16: Emmeline Pankhurst was a British political activist and leader of the British suffragette movement. Born in Manchester to politically active parents, she was introduced to the women's suffrage movement at the age of 8. After her husband's death in 1898, Pankhurst founded the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU), an organisation dedicated to 'deeds, not words'. The all-women group placed itself separately from, and often in opposition to, political parties. The WSPU became infamous when its members smashed windows and assaulted police officers as part of their campaigning. Pankhurst was widely criticised for her militant tactics, but her work is recognised as crucial in achieving women's right to vote in Britain.

column14: Sir Edward Burne-Jones (1833-1898) artist lived here 1865-1867
column16: Sir Edward Burne-Jones was a British artist and designer closely associated with the later phase of the Pre-Raphaelite movement. He created a number of famed paintings, as well as stained glass works for several churches. He co-founded Morris, Marshall, Faulkner & Co. with William Morris and other artists associated with the Pre-Raphaelite movement. He also produced many engravings for Morris' Kelmscott Press. With an abiding interest in the decorative arts, Burne-Jones also designed ceramic tiles, jewellery, tapestries, mosaics and book illustrations; he is considered one of the most influential artists of the 19th century. He lived in Kensington Square for two years, where his daughter Margaret was born.

column14: Walter Sickert (1860-1942) Painter and etcher lived and worked here
column16: Walter Richard Sickert was a painter who had an important influence on distinctively British styles of avant-garde art in the 20th century. Sickert was a cosmopolitan and eccentric artist who often favoured ordinary people and urban scenes as his subjects. He often included well-known personalities and images derived from press photographs. Sickert took a keen interest in the crimes of Jack the Ripper, believing he had lodged in a room used by the serial killer- some historians have since claimed that Sickert was the notorious murderer, but this claim has been dismissed by just as many.

column14: Ivor Novello (1893-1951) Composer and Actor Manager lived and died in a flat on the top floor of this building,
column16: Ivor Novello was a composer, actor, theatre manager and singer who became one the most influential British entertainers of the first half of the 20th century. Born into a musical family, his first successes were as a songwriter. His first big hit was 'Keep The Home Fires Burning', which was enormously popular during WW1. After the war, Novello contributed songs to several successful musical comedies, and wrote complete scores for shows, before turning to acting in the 1920's. Four years after his death the Ivor Novello Awards for song writing were established in his memory.

column14: Bertrand Russell (1872-1970) Philosopher and Campaigner for Peace lived here in flat No.34 1911-1916
column16: Bertrand Russell was a British philosopher, logician, social critic and campaigner for peace. He was born in Monmouthshire and educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; he made several key contributions to twentieth century mathematics and philosophy, and is considered by many to have led the British 'revolt against idealism'. Russell lived in this house during the First World War, during which time he was prominent in the anti-war movement. Russell established the Russell Tribunal during the Vietnam War, which is now known as the International War Crimes Tribunal.

column14: Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837) Clown lived here.
column16: Joseph Grimaldi was an English actor and comedian who is best known for his invention of the modern day whiteface clown. He was born into a family of performers, and made his stage debut aged three. As a pantomime clown Grimaldi was considered unsurpassable, his greatest success occurring in 'Harlequin and Mother Goose; or the Golden Egg' at Theatre Royal, Covent Garden. He was an innovator, and his performance as Joey introduced the modern clown to the world. To this day clowns gather annually in full attire at Holy Trinity Church in Dalston, London to celebrate his life.

column14: In 1926 in this house John Logie Baird (1888-1946) first demonstrated television.
column16: John Logie Baird was a Scottish engineer who is most famous for inventing television. Baird showed ingenuity from an early age, rigging a telephone exchange from his bedroom to communicate with friends from across the street. In the early 1920s Baird made his major breakthrough with transmitting moving images, initially just  silhouettes, but he soon managed grey, tonal images. In 1926, on the top floor of this house in Frith Street, he first demonstrated this type of transmission to members of the Royal Institution and a reporter from the Times newspaper. Baird went on to make major contributions to the development of colour television and broadcasting.

column14: Anna Freud (1895-1982) Pioneer of Child Psychoanalysis lived here 1938-1982
column16: Anna Freud was the sixth and last child of Sigmund and Martha Freud. Born in Vienna, she followed the path of her father and contributed much to the fledgling field of psychoanalysis. Alongside Melanie Klein, she may be considered the founder of psychoanalytic child psychology. Anna moved to Hampstead in 1938 after fleeing Austria, and the harassment of Jews by the Nazis. Much of her important work with children occurred during and immediately after the Second World War, when she observed the effects of stress and lack of parental care on children.

column14: Richard Burton (1925-1984) Actor lived here 1949-1956
column16: Richard Burton was a Welsh actor who appeared in over seventy films, and was nominated for seven Academy Awards. Born into a working class mining family, he began smoking and drinking at a very young age, both of which he was notorious for throughout his life. He was a gifted soprano singer and actor and mentored by his schoolmaster, was encouraged to pursue acting as a career. Burton lived in this house while appearing in several British films and stage productions. In 1952 Burton successfully made the transition to Hollywood, becoming for a time its most highly paid actor. In 1963 he appeared in Cleopatra with Elizabeth Taylor, to whom he was famously twice married.

column14: John Lennon (1940-1980) Musician and Songwriter lived here in 1968
column16: John Lennon was an English musician and songwriter, who rose to worldwide fame in the 1960s as a member of the Beatles, and then as a solo artist in the 1970s.  He is considered to be one of the greatest songwriters of all time, penning some of the most successful pop songs with fellow Beatle Paul McCartney. As well as enjoying immense success as a musician, Lennon also made a significant impact on the anti-war campaign during the Vietnam War. Lennon lived in his house on Montagu Square in 1968, the same year that the Beatles recorded The White Album, following a highly influential visit to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in India. He was killed by a fan outside his New York apartment in 1980.

column14: Sir Henry Wood (1869-1944) Musician lived here
column16: Sir Henry Joseph Wood was an English conductor best known for his association with London's annual season of classical concerts. Began in 1895, they were to be a season of informal indoor recitals in the style of outdoor 'promenade concerts', where the audience was free to stroll around; the aim being to introduce classical and modern music to a completely new crowd. Wood was appointed as its first conductor, and continued to be for nearly 50 years, introducing hundreds of new works to British audiences. After his death, the concerts were officially renamed 'The Henry Wood Promenade Concerts' in his honour, but are still commonly referred to as 'The Proms'.

column14: Ralph Vaughan Williams O.M. (1872-1958) Composer lived here from 1953 until his death
column16: Ralph Vaughan Williams was an English composer of symphonies, chamber music, opera, choral music, and film scores. Educated at Cambridge, and later a pupil of the Royal College of Music, Williams made a considerable contribution to English music. His greatest achievement is considered to be the work for 'The English Hymnal' a collection of hymns in the English language. He also toured the British countryside collecting traditional folk songs and carols, many of which were passed on verbally and otherwise not recorded, so saving many from being lost forever. Williams lived in the house on Hanover Terrace from 1953 until his death five years later.

column14: David Edward Hughes (1831-1900) Scientist and inventor of the microphone lived and worked here
column16: David Edward Hughes was a British scientist, inventor and musician. He was responsible for some of the most important inventions of the modern age, including the international standard Hughes' Telegraph System. He was the inventor of crystal radio, spark-gap technology and his pioneering radio work was later built upon by Marconi & Hertz, amongst others. He is best known for inventing the microphone, and which he used in many of his studies and discoveries in the field of radio technology.

column14: Sir George Cayley (1773-1857) Scientist and pioneer of aviation lived here
column16: Sir George Cayley was a prolific English engineer and a pioneer of aeronautics; he is known as the father of Aerodynamics. Cayley designed the first ever glider to successfully carry a human aloft and discovered and identified the aerodynamic forces of flight: weight, lift, drag and thrust. His findings were key to the Wright Brothers later success. Modern aeroplane design is based on all of those principles, as well as his invention, cambered wings.

column14: Ada Countess of Lovelace (1815-1852) Pioneer of Computing lived here
column16: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace was born Augusta Ada Byron, daughter of poet Lord Byron. She was known chiefly for her work on Charles Babbage's early mechanical computer, the Analytical Engine. She was a skilled mathematician, and Babbage called her 'an enchantress of numbers'. Her notes on the engine include what is recognised as the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine; she is considered to be the world's first computer programmer.

column14: Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) The pioneer of wireless communication lived here in 1896-1897
column16: Guglielmo Marconi was an Italian inventor and businessman. Marconi is often credited as the inventor of radio, commercialising earlier experimentations and ideas of others. He had many successes but it was the transmission of radio signal across the Atlantic for which Marconi is known as a true innovator. Dismissed in Italy, he came to London in 1896 to seek support for his work, so meeting the chief electrical engineer of the Post Office, William Preece, who became one of his most ardent supporters. He lived in this house with his mother during this time.

column14: Eleanor Rathbone (1872-1946) Pioneer of Family Allowances lived here
column16: Eleanor Rathbone was an independent British Member of Parliament and long-term campaigner for women's rights. Her early life focused on women's political and social rights, including campaigning for an allowance to be paid directly to mothers, which was heavily influenced by her research into the lives of the poor in Liverpool. After WWI Rathbone continued her lobbying for social reform and grew increasingly, and publicly, concerned with international developments, notably the Spanish Civil War and the nature of Nazi Germany.  Rathbone was instrumental in the introduction of the Family Allowances Act of 1945, which became law just a year before her death.

column14: Virginia Stephen (Woolf) (1882-1941) Novelist and Critic lived here 1907-1911
column16: Virginia Woolf was an English writer. During the interwar period, she was a significant figure in London literary society and a member of the famed Bloomsbury Group. In 1917 she founded the Hogarth Press with her husband Leonard, which published works of the group. Her most noted novels include 'Mrs Dalloway (1925), 'To The Lighthouse' (1927) and 'Orlando' (1928). She also wrote the book-length essay 'A Room of One's Own' (1929), with its famous dictum, 'A woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction', a comment on both the education and creative freedoms of women. Woolf suffered severely from depression and in 1941 she filled her overcoat pockets with stones, walked into the River Ouse near her home, and drowned.

column14: Alan Turing (1912-1954) Code-breaker and Pioneer of Computer Science was born here
column16: Alan Mathison Turing was an English mathematician, logician, cryptanalyst, and computer scientist; he is widely considered to be the father of computer science and artificial intelligence. His 'Turing' machine played a significant role in the creation of the modern computer and his work at Bletchley Park during World War Two was critical to the breaking of the German Enigma Code, a key step to winning the war. In 1952, when homosexuality was still illegal, Turing was charged with 'gross indecency', when his relationship with another man became known. Avoiding prison by accepting a course of chemical castration, he died two years later by ingesting cyanide. In 2009 he received a posthumous public apology from the British Government for his ill treatment.

column14: George Frideric Handel (1685-1759) Composer lived in this house from 1723 and died here
column16: George Frederic Handel was a German-British Baroque composer, famous for his operas, oratorios, anthems and organ concertos; he is regarded as one of the greatest composers of all time. His early career was dominated by Italian opera, but it is his English choral work for which he is perhaps best known. These include 'Messiah' and 'Zadok the Priest'. Handel moved to this house in 1723, which he rented for the rest of his life, and is now a museum to his life and work.

column14: Jimi Hendrix (1942-1970) Guitarist and songwriter lived here 1968-1969
column16: James Marshall 'Jimi' Hendrix was an American guitarist and singer-songwriter. He is widely considered to be the greatest electric guitarist in music history, and one of the most influential musicians of his era. Hendrix, along with his friend Eric Clapton, was a pioneer of performance and music production, popularising the use of the wah-wah pedal in mainstream rock and the technique of guitar amplifier feedback. Hendrix gained an early and enthusiastic following in London; he lived in a flat here in Brook Street in 1969 with girlfriend Kathy Etchingham.

column14: In a house on this site in 1764-5 Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791) lived, played and composed
column16: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was an Austrian composer, widely recognised as one of the greatest in the history of Western classical music. Mozart showed prodigious talent from an early age, touring the Royal Courts of Europe as a child prodigy; he began composing at the age of five. Mozart travelled to London in 1764-5 where he met Johann Christian Bach (youngest son of J S Bach) who was to prove a key influence. Mozart composed over 600 works in many musical genres, including the 'The Magic Flute'.

column14: In a house on this site Florence Nightingale (1820-1910) lived and died
column16: Florence Nightingale was a celebrated English nurse, writer and statistician. She came to prominence for her pioneering work in nursing during the Crimean War (1853-1856), when she was dubbed the 'Lady with the Lamp' after her habit of making rounds at night. Educated and from a privileged background, Nightingale believed that God had called her to be a nurse. She laid the foundation of professional nursing with the establishment of her nursing school at St Thomas' Hospital in London in 1860; it was the first secular nursing school in the world. Aside from her achievements in nursing, she became the first female member of the Royal Statistical society in 1859, and her writings are considered significant in the history of women's literature.

column14: Samuel Morse (1791-1872) American painter, and inventor of the Morse Code lived here 1812-1815
column16: Samuel Finley Breese Morse was an American painter and inventor. He co-invented Morse code, and was a key contributor in the development of long-range telegraph systems. In 1825, away from home on a painting commission, he was told of his wife's ill health by horse messenger (at the time the fastest way to carry news). Returning too late, he was heartbroken to learn of her lonely death. He gave up painting, and began to pursue a means of rapid long distance communication. Morse developed a code to be transmitted as a series of dots and dashes, plus the concept of a single-wire telegraph, to transmit the code. Morse's code was the forerunner to international version still in use today.

column14: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936) poet and story writer lived here 1889-1891
column16: Rudyard Kipling was an English poet and writer. He is chiefly known for his works of fiction including 'The Jungle Book' and the 'Just So Stories', and is regarded as a major innovator in the art of the short story. Kipling was one of the most popular writers in England at the turn of the 20th century, and in 1907 became the youngest recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature. He travelled widely, spending two years at this house in Charing Cross, and where he wrote novels, and stories for several magazines. He was also married in London, in 1892.

column14: William Daniell (1769-1837) Artist and engraver of Indian scenes lived and died here
column16: William Daniell RA was an English landscape and marine painter, and engraver. He travelled extensively in the Far East, producing one of the finest illustrated volumes of the period, entitled 'Oriental Scenery'. He also toured the British coastline painting watercolours for the equally ambitious book 'A Voyage Round Great Britain'. His work was much exhibited and in 1822 he became a Royal Academician. Daniell excelled in transferring his pictures to prints using the aquatint technique, which he spent many years perfecting, and published several successful editions of his works. In 1962 several of his original plates were re-discovered, and which now belong to the Tate Galleries.

column14: Captain Matthew Flinders, R.N. (1774-1814) Explorer and Navigator lived here
column16: Captain Matthew Flinders was one of the most successful navigators and cartographers of his age. Inspired by Daniel Defoe's 'Robinson Crusoe' Flinders was the first explorer to circumnavigate Australia, and encouraged the use of that name for the continent, which was previously known as New Holland. Flinders also invented the iron bars commonly used to compensate for the magnetic deviations on board ships; they are now known as Flinders Bars.

column14: John Harrison (1693-1776) inventor of the Marine Chronometer lived and died in a house on this site
column16: John Harrison was a self-educated carpenter and later a clockmaker. He is most famous for his invention in 1737 of the first reliable marine chronometer. This long-sought device solved the problem of establishing the East-West position (or longitude) of a ship at sea, so revolutionising marine travel in the eighteenth century by safely extending the distances ships could travel, whilst staying on course. Harrison spent his last years in this house in Red Lion Square and is buried in the graveyard of St John's Church, Hampstead.

column14: Site of the business premises of Thomas Earnshaw (1749-1829) noted watch and chronometer maker
column16: Thomas Earnshaw was an English watchmaker, who is known as a pioneer of chronometer development. It was Earnshaw who further simplified the production process of the marine chronometer (a device used to measure the east-west position of a ship at sea), making them more affordable, and so available to the general public. An Earnshaw chronometer was used aboard HMS Beagle, during Charles Darwin's 5-year voyage, which inspired his theory of evolution.

column14: John Desmond Bernal (1901-1971) Crystallographer lived and died here
column16: John Desmond Bernal was a British writer, political activist, and physicist best known for his major contributions to X-ray crystallography. At Cambridge University Bernal initiated a research program of X-ray investigations into the structure of complex biological molecules, which resulted in Nobel-level discoveries by his students and co-workers. Bernal also made a significant contributions to the Normandy landings of WWII, comprehensively mapping the coast line, and helping to design an artificial harbour called a Mulberry, which were used extensively in the landings.

column6: Biological Sciences Building, University College, (site of 110) Gower Street
column14: Charles Darwin (1809-1882) Naturalist lived in a house on this site 1838-1842
column16: Charles Robert Darwin was an English naturalist, and one of the most influential figures in human history. Darwin established that all species of life have descended from common ancestry, proposing the scientific theory of natural selection. He published his theory as 'On The Origin Of Species' in 1859, which is considered the foundation of evolutionary biology. Darwin lived in a house formerly on this site, from 1838-1842, a time when he first conceived his theory, following his 5-year voyage aboard the HMS Beagle.

column14: Ian Fleming (1908-1964) Creator of James Bond lived here
column16: Ian Fleming was an English author best known for creating the fictional spy James Bond and the many novels and stories featuring the character. The Bond books are the biggest-selling series of fictional books of all time, having sold over 100 million copies worldwide. Fleming also wrote the much-loved children's story 'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' about a flying car. His experiences of the people he met during his time spent as a naval intelligence officer for Britain during WWII provided much of the inspiration and detail for his novels, the first of which was 'Casino Royale', published  in 1953. Fleming was a heavy smoker and drinker and suffered from heart disease; he died of a heart attack aged just 56.

column14: Augustus Siebe (1788-1872) Pioneer of the Diving Helmet lived and worked here
column16: Augustus Siebe was a German-born British engineer known chiefly for his contributions to the diving industry. Siebe moved to London in 1816 where he became in turn a watchmaker, gun maker, instrument maker and finally a mechanical engineer. After being approached in 1830 by the Deane Brothers (inventors of the smoke helmet), Siebe began designing and building diving equipment, producing a helmet fitted to a full-length watertight canvas diving suit. This design became standard diving dress, which revolutionised underwater civil engineering and salvage, and commercial and naval diving. He lived and worked at 5 Denmark St.

column14: Ebenezer Howard (1850-1928) Pioneer of the Garden City Movement
column16: Sir Ebenezer Howard is best known for his publication 'Garden Cities of To-morrow', where he describes a utopian city of people living harmoniously together with nature. Howard's vision was of a self-sufficient city of 32,000 people, on a site of 6000 hectares. It was planned on a concentric pattern with open spaces, public parks and six radial boulevards extending from the centre. The publication resulted in the founding of the garden city movement, which realised several garden cities in Great Britain following the passing of the New Towns Act in 1946. The movement was also greatly influential in America.

column6: Camden School for Girls, Sandall Road
column14: Frances Mary Buss (1827-1898) Pioneer of Education of Women was Headmistress here 1879-1894
column16: Frances Mary Buss was an English pioneer of women's education. Buss was at the forefront of campaigns for the endowment of girls' schools, for girls to be allowed to sit public examinations, to enter universities, and for women's rights to vote. The daughter of Robert William Buss and Frances Fleetwood, Buss attended a local free school where she began teaching at the age of fourteen. Buss established the North London Collegiate School for Girls in 1850, followed by Camden School for Girls in 1871, where she was headmistress until her death in 1894.

column14: George Orwell (1903-1950) Novelist and political essayist lived here
column16: Eric Arthur Blair (1903-1950) was an English novelist and journalist, better known by his pen name George Orwell. Considered perhaps the 20th century's best chronicler of English culture, Orwell wrote literary criticism, poetry, fiction and polemical journalism. He is best known for the dystopian novel 'Nineteen Eighty-Four', (written in 1948) and the earlier allegorical novella 'Animal Farm', which together have sold more copies than any two books by any other 20th-century author. Orwell's influence on popular and political culture endures, and the term 'Orwellian', a byword for totalitarian or manipulative social practices, has long since entered the everyday language.

column14: Ford Madox Brown (1821-1893) Painter lived here
column16: Ford Madox Brown was an English painter of moral and historical subjects, notable for his distinctly graphic version of the Pre-Raphaelite style. Although not a member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, Brown remained closely linked to them and he was a tutor to the young Dante Gabriel Rossetti. Brown's most famous painting is arguably 'Work' which attempts to depict in a single image the entire spectrum of social experience, in mid-Victorian England.

column14: Thomas Hosmer Shepherd (1793-1864) Artist who portrayed London lived here
column16: Thomas Hosmer Shepherd was a watercolour artist known for his works on architecture. Shepherd was employed to illustrate buildings in London, and later Edinburgh, Bath and Bristol. His paintings were the basis for steel engravings, reproduced in many books. Shepherd's work is characterised by an attention to detail, with life-like scenes containing people, carriages and horses. He worked mostly for Frederick Crace, who employed him to paint London buildings prior to their demolition, and much of his work belongs in the Crace collection at the British Museum.

column14: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe (1900-1996) Landscape Architect lived here 1936-1984
column16: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe was an English landscape architect, garden designer, architect and designer, and considered to be one of the greatest of his generation. Jellicoe was born in Chelsea and studied at the Architectural Association in London before travelling to Rome in 1923. In Italy Jellicoe undertook an extensive study of renaissance gardens, which were in a state of decay at the time, and this inspired much of his landscape architecture. Some of his key design projects included the design of new town Hemel Hempstead, Ditchley Park in Oxfordshire, Sutton Place in Surrey and the John F Kennedy memorial, also in Surrey.

column14: Mary Kingsley (1862-1900) Traveller and ethnologist lived here as a child
column16: Mary Henrietta Kingsley was an English writer and pioneering explorer of west Africa, who greatly influenced European ideas about Africa and African people. Having lived a sheltered life and never marrying, Kingsley travelled to west Africa after the death of her father, George Kingsley. It was highly unusual for a woman of Kingsley's race, age and gender to embark on such a dangerous journey unaccompanied, and despite several close encounters with crocodiles, cannibalistic tribesmen and disease Kingsley's publications and lectures were remarkably modest. She made a significant impact on ideas of the colonialism of Africa.

column14: H.G. Wells (1866-1946) Writer lived and died here
column16: HG Wells was an English author who is widely regarded as one of the founders of modern science fiction.  His background in sciences (he studied biology and was a science teacher) together with his interest in socialist ideas were formative themes in his writings. His novels include  'The Time Machine' (1895), 'The Island of Doctor Moreau' (1896), and 'The War of the Worlds' (1898) which is probably his best known. His intellectually provocative stories touched on the changes in the meaning of human life, informed by dramatic social and industrial changes of the time, but set far in the future, and have influenced popular culture ever since their first publication.

column14: Mahatma Gandhi (1869-1948) stayed here in 1931
column16: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, more often referred to as Mahatma Gandhi, was a lawyer and the political and ideological leader of India during the Indian independence movement. Gandhi's model of non-violent fight for civil rights and freedom, that he called 'satyagraha', inspired movements across the world. Gaandi stayed here in 1931 during negotiations between the British government and the Indian nation, when he was the sole representative of the Indian National Congress. The Gandhi-Irwin pact (Lord Irwin was then Viceroy of India) was signed in March 1931, with Gandhi agreeing to end the civil disobedience movement.

column14: John McDouall Stuart (1815-1866) First Explorer to cross Australia lived and died here
column16: John McDouall Stuart was a Scottish explorer, and the first man to successfully lead an expedition across the Australian mainland. Stuart trained as civil engineer before emigrating to Australia in 1838. He led a total of six expeditions, completing the first successful south to north journey from Adelaide to Darwin in 1862. The town Alice Springs was originally named 'Stuart' in his honour, before being changed in 1933. Stuart died here in London in 1866.

column14: Robert Falcon Scott (1868-1912) Antarctic explorer lived here
column16: Robert Falcon Scott was a Royal Navy officer and explorer who famously led two scientific expeditions to the Antarctic regions: the Discovery Expedition of 1901-04, and the ill-fated Terra Nova Expedition of 1910-13. During this second venture, Scott's party reached the South Pole on 17 January 1912, only to find that they had been beaten by Roald Amundsen's Norwegian expedition. On their return journey, Scott and his four comrades all perished from a combination of exhaustion, starvation and extreme cold, only a few miles short of crucial supplies. Scott's exploration of the Antarctic has made his name synonymous with the region, and he is regarded today as a brave and stoic leader.

column14: Edward Adrian Wilson (1872-1912) Antarctic explorer and naturalist lived here
column16: Edward A Wilson was a polar explorer and expedition artist. Wilson travelled on two Antarctic expeditions aboard the Discovery (1901-1904) and on Terra Nova (1910-1912) both under the leadership of Robert Falcon Scott. Wilson joined the Discovery expedition as junior surgeon, zoologist and expedition artist, and he was chief of the scientific staff of Scott's final Terra Nova expedition. Wilson was the confidant of many of the men during these trips, respected for his judgement, mediatory skills and dedication to others. He was probably Scott's closest comrade, perishing with him and the other members of the group on the return leg of the Terra Nova, after discovering that Norwayês Amundsen had beaten them to the South Pole.

column14: Dr John Snow (1813-1858) pioneer anaesthetist and epidemiologist lived in a house on this site.
column16: John Snow was an English physician and a pioneer of anaesthesia and epidemiology. His use of chloroform and ether as surgical anaesthetics, allowed surgical procedures without the distress and pain patients would otherwise experience. He is best known, however, for his work in 1854 in tracing the source of a cholera outbreak in Soho. Snow used a map to illustrate the cluster of cases around a water pump in Broadwick Street (where a memorial pump now stands), and used statistics to illustrate the connection between the water source and the cholera cases. As a result he is considered the founding father of epidemiology, which deals with detection of both the source and cause of epidemics of infectious disease in large populations.

column14: Sir Charles Wheatstone (1802-1875) Scientist and Inventor lived here
column16: Sir Charles Wheatstone was an English scientist and inventor, who was responsible for numerous key scientific breakthroughs of the Victorian era. Wheatstone had a keen interest in musical instruments and the science of sound, inventing the English concertina. He also went on to make several significant contributions to optics, notably the stereoscope, to view 3D images, and he is widely credited as the first to make telegraph transmission of messages available to the public. His many innovations were some of the most important of the age, and his influence continues to be felt today.

column14: Sir Benjamin Count Rumford (1753-1814) Inventor and Adventurer lived here
column16: Sir Benjamin Thompson, Count Rumford was an American-born British physicist and inventor; as a Loyalist he had fled to Britain during the American Revolutionary War. Thompsonês experiments with heat were hugely significant and he was also a prolific inventor, developing a kitchen range, a drip coffeepot and improved candles and oil lamps. His most noted domestic contribution was the Rumford Fireplace, which improved airflow in open fireplaces so removing choking smoke from the home and increasing heating efficiency; it was a hugely popular modification to homes in the 19th century.

column14: Dennis Gabor (1900-1979) Physicist and Inventor of Holography lived here
column16: Dennis Gabor was a Hungarian-British electrical engineer and inventor; he was originally from Budapest and studied in Berlin before fleeing Nazi Germany in 1933. Gabor was a great success as chair of applied electron physics at Imperial College London. His most significant achievement was his invention of holography in 1947, the method to produce holograms, for which he received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1971. Although it was not until 1961 that its use could be properly realised due to the development of lasers, holography made a remarkable impact on many sciences, arts and commercial products.

column14: Joseph Aloysius Hansom (1803-1882) Architect, founder-editor of 'The Builder' and inventor of the Hansom Cab lived here
column16: Joseph Aloysius Hansom was a prolific English architect, but he is best known for inventing the Hansom safety cab in 1834. This was an improved horse-drawn (or 'Hackney') carriage that was fast, light and agile, requiring only one horse instead of the usual four. It made a significant impact on London transport, becoming the hire-cab of choice. Later models were fitted with a fare meter, and these were the forerunners to todays black taxis, still known today as Hackney Cabs. Hansom also founded eminent architectural magazine 'The Builder' in 1842, which is still published today.

column14: Keith Moon (1946-1978) legendary rock drummer with 'The Who' performed here at the site of the Marquee Club in the 1960s
column16: Keith Moon was an English musician, best known as the drummer of the English rock group The Who. He gained acclaim for his exuberant and innovative drumming style, and notoriety for his eccentric and often self-destructive behaviour, earning him the nickname 'Moon the Loon'.  He joined The Who aged 17, and the band quickly gained attention for destroying their onstage equipment at the end of their performances,  and for Moon trashing hotel rooms. Despite his notoriously destructive ways, Moon is widely considered to be the greatest rock drummer of all time.

column14: John Rae (1813-1893) Arctic explorer lived and died here
column16: John Rae was a Scottish doctor and pioneering Arctic explorer. Rae was adept at travelling light with a small crew and using Inuit techniques of hunting. He became famous, however, for reporting the fate in 1854 of the Franklin Expedition; a naval team that had departed England nine years earlier in search of the final unchartered stretch of Canada's Northwest Passage. The expedition had become became icebound, losing all 128 men, and Raeês report of the stricken crew included evidence of cannibalism. Until then many others had tried unsuccessfully, often fatally, to locate the missing party. Instead of being hailed a hero, his 'outrageous claims' of such desperate behaviour led to Rae being publicly spurned and as a result, he never received any honours.

column14: Sir James Clark Ross (1800-1862) Polar Explorer lived here
column16: Sir James Clark Ross was a British naval officer and polar explorer. In 1827 he was part of the expedition led by his uncle Sir John Ross, which discovered the magnetic North Pole. Ross led numerous expeditions, many in a quest to locate the magnetic South Pole. In this he was unsuccessful, but his explorations of the Antarctic coast led to him charting many land masses and seas, including the Ross Ice Shelf, Ross Sea, James Ross Island, and the volcanoes Mount Erebus and Mount Terror, named after the expedition's vessels. In 1848 he led an unsuccessful attempt to locate the ill-fated Franklin Expedition, which was found six years later.

column14: Sir Ernest Shackleton (1874-1922) Antarctic Explorer lived here
column16: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton was a famed Anglo-Irish polar explorer. Gaining valuable experience on Robert Scott's Discovery expedition, he commanded three voyages of his own, most famously the 'Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition' of 1914-1916, involving the ships Endurance & the Aurora. Crushed by pack-ice, The Endurance was sunk (after the crew abandoned ship), and the Aurora broke free of its moorings, unable to return for men on the shore. The men were scattered, but after several exploits including an 800-mile open-boat journey by Shackleton and a small crew to find help, all the surviving men were eventually rescued. Only 3 men lost their lives during the entire expedition, so ensuring Shackleton's heroic status, for his determination in the face of adversity.

column14: In a house on this site lived from 1854-1875 Sir Charles Lyell (1797-1875) Geologist and from 1876-1882 W.E. Gladstone Statesman (1809-1898)
column16: Sir Charles Lyell was a British lawyer and the foremost geologist of his day. He is best known as the author of 'Principles of Geology', which popularised the concepts of uniformitarianism: the idea that the earth was shaped by slow-moving forces. Lyellês book was hugely influential on Charles Darwin, who carried a volume with him on his voyage aboard the Beagle, giving him a revolutionary insight into geological history of the islands he explored. On returning from that voyage, Darwin and Lyell became close friends. Prime Minister William Ewart Gladstone also lived here.

column14: Thomas Young (1773-1829) Man of Science lived here
column16: Thomas Young was an English polymath, scientist and Egyptologist. He is famous for his part-deciphering of Egyptian hieroglyphics (specifically the Rosetta Stone) before Jean-Francois Champollion eventually expanded on his work. Young also made notable contributions to the fields of vision, light, solid mechanics, energy, physiology, language and musical harmony; his work was admired by, among others, the astronomer Herschel, and physicist Albert Einstein.

column14: Sir Francis Beaufort (1774-1857) Admiral and Hydrographer lived here
column16: Rear-Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort was an Irish hydrographer and officer in Britain's Royal Navy. He was shipwrecked at the age of 15, and dedicated the rest of his life to improving the accuracy of sea-charts, to aid those risking their lives at sea. His greatest accomplishments were achieved in nautical charting, particularly in South America. It was during his sea voyages in the navy that Beaufort developed the first versions of his Wind Force Scale and coding, known as the Beaufort scale, and still in use today.

column14: James Smithson (1764-1829) Scientist Founder of the Smithsonian Institution lived here
column16: James Smithson was a British mineralogist and chemist whose place in history is unique, as his fame came almost entirely posthumously. In his will of 1826, Smithson donated his complete and considerable fortune to the government of the United States of America to 'found in Washington under the name of the Smithsonian Institution, an establishment for the increase and diffusion of knowledge among men'. The Smithsonian Institution is now the largest museum complex in the world, with 136 million items in its collections.

column14: Major-General William Roy (1726-1790) Founder of the Ordnance Survey lived here
column16: Major-General William Roy FRS was a Scottish military engineer, surveyor, and antiquarian. He is credited as founder of the Ordnance Survey, the national mapping agency of Great Britain. In 1747 it was proposed that the Scottish Highlands be surveyed and mapped, and Roy found himself as assistant on this task. His technical ability and innovative approach made him a key member of the team. His abilities and leadership led to a long and illustrious career in the Royal Engineers, with Roy responsible for some of the most important surveys in cartographic history. The Ordnance Survey was founded in 1791, a year after his death.

column14: Mary Shelley (1797-1851) Author of Frankenstein lived here 1846-1851
column16: Mary Shelley was an English writer, best known for her Gothic novel 'Frankenstein: or, The Modern Prometheus'. The novel resulted from a competition 'to write the best horror story', held amongst her companions , who included her husband, the noted poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, Lord Byron and John Polidori- all key figures in the Romantic movement. First published anonymously in 1818, as an edition of just 500, it has since been re-published hundreds of times in numerous languages, and has spawned many plays, films and other adaptations. Her father was the political philosopher William Godwin, and her mother was the philosopher and feminist Mary Wollstonecraft.

column14: Sir Ambrose Fleming (1849-1945) Scientist and Electrical Engineer lived here
column16: Sir John Ambrose Fleming was an English electrical engineer and physicist. He was the inventor of the first thermionic valve (or vacuum tube), which was pivotal in the development of electronic technology, and was used in radio receivers and radars for many years after. Fleming was a consultant to some of the most influential businesses of the time including the Marconi Company and the Edison Telephone and Edison Electric light companies. The impact of his innovations can be felt still today: from plasma TVs to radios, and radar to car engines.

column14: Sir Isaac Newton (1642-1727) Lived Here
column16: Sir Isaac Newton was an English physicist, mathematician, astronomer, natural philosopher, alchemist, and theologian; he is considered to be one of the greatest and most influential scientists of all time. Newton's theory of gravity, inspired by an apple falling from a tree, was hugely significant and a key idea in the Scientific Revolution. As a young boy, his mother wished for him to be a farmer, but he was persuaded to complete his education by his schoolmaster. Newton lived here in Jermyn Street when appointed warden of the Royal Mint in 1696, and he campaigned against corruption and inefficiency in the organisation. He was also president of the Royal Society, from 1703 until his death.

column14: Hertha Ayrton (1854-1923) Physicist lived here 1903-1923
column16: Hertha Ayrton was an English engineer, mathematician and inventor. Ayrton was educated at Girton College, Cambridge at a time when women were only awarded certificates, not degrees by the college; she gained a degree in 1881 from the University of London. She would assist her husband in his experiments in physics and electricity, which led to her own investigations into the electric arc; she became the first female member of the Institution of Electrical Engineers. In 1902 she was rejected as a fellow of the Royal Society, on the grounds that 'married women were not eligible', but was later awarded the Hughes Medal for her research.  Although agnostic, she established the Jewish League for Women's Suffrage, in 1912.

column14: Leonard Huxley (1860-1933) Julian Huxley (1887-1975) Aldous Huxley (1894-1963) Men of Science and Letters lived here
column16: Aldous Huxley was a writer whose best known for his novel 'Brave New World'. Written in 1931, it describes a dystopian and terrifying future world. Huxley was reacting to the rapid changes in society, as a result of the industrial revolution, and to key world events such as the Russian Revolution and WW1. It is considered one of the greatest and influential novels of the 20th century.  He was from the great Huxley family, and here lived here with his father Leonard (son of Thomas Henry Huxley, known as 'Darwins Bulldog'), and his brother Sir Julian Huxley, an evolutionary biologist.

column14: SirWilliam Ramsay (1852-1916) Chemist Discoverer of the Noble Gases lived here 1887-1902
column16: Sir William Ramsay was a Scottish chemist who was the most famous scientist of his time. Ramsay's main achievement was the discovery, and subsequent research into, the group of chemical elements known as the 'noble gases'. These include neon, helium, krypton, and they all have many important industrial, medical, and scientific applications. In 1904, Ramsay became the first British recipient of the Nobel Prize for chemistry, in recognition of his unique achievements. He was immensely popular with both students and colleagues, and was nicknamed 'the Chief'.

column14: Sir William Crookes (1832-1919) Scientist lived here from 1880 until his death
column16: Sir William Crookes was a pioneering British chemist and scientific journalist. Having attended the Royal College of Chemistry in London from 1850 to 1854, Crookes went on to make several notable discoveries and inventions; most famously the element 'thallium' and also a type of vacuum, named the 'Crookes tube', which would prove instrumental in the discovery of X-rays. Crookes was a brilliant experimentalist and his eclectic interests made him a well-known personality in Victorian Britain, and he received many public and academic honours. His house at 7 Kensington Park Gardens was the first home in England to be lit by electricity.

column14: Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952) Scientist and Statesman First President of the State of Israel lived here
column16: Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952) was a scientist and politician. Weizmann trained as a chemist in mainland Europe and after moving to the UK, was credited with developing a method to produce acetone from maize, which was needed for the production of artillery shells during WWI. However, he is most famous for becoming the first president of the state of Israel in 1949, having been integral to its creation as a Zionist leader. It was in London that Weizmann was successful in securing the Balfour Declaration of 1917 in which the British government supported the creation of a Zionist state in Palestine.

column14: Sir Norman Lockyer (1836-1920) Astronomer, Physicist and Founder of Nature lived here 1876-1920
column16: Norman Lockyer was an English scientist and astronomer who is most famous for discovering the element helium. In the 1860s, he became interested in electromagnetic spectroscopy, the study of the interaction between matter and radiated energy, leading him to observe an unknown element emitted from the sun.  'Helium' is from the Greek word 'Helios' meaning sun. As well as his astronomical work, Lockyer also founded the journal 'Nature' in 1869, to facilitate sharing of ideas between scientists, and it is still published today.

column6: The Elms, 29-32 Clapham Common North Side
column14: Sir Charles Barry (1795-1860) Architect lived and died here
column16: Sir Charles Barry was one of the most famous architects of the 19th century, and is best known for his role in the rebuilding the Houses of Parliament, also known as the Palace of Westminster, after the original was destroyed by fire in 1834. Barry's design for the building was distinctly Gothic, which reflected the Victorian fashions of the time. A landmark building, it incorporates a great clock tower that is commonly known as 'Big Ben', although this is the name for the huge bell housed inside. Barry also designed the Manchester Art Gallery, and remodelled Trafalgar Square in 1845; he was knighted in 1852, marking the completion of the Palace of Westminster.

column14: John Francis Bentley (1839-1902) Architect lived here
column16: John Francis Bentley was an English architect, most famous for designing Westminster Cathedral in 1894. Bentley's design for the new Roman Catholic cathedral was heavily influenced by the Byzantine style of architecture that enjoyed a revival in the 19th century. His design was inspired by Italian cathedrals such as St Mark's Basilica in Venice, which he visited in 1894. The design and construction of the cathedral was warmly received, and praised for its simplicity of decoration and its immense scale.

column14: Lancelot 'Capability' Brown (1716-1783) Landscape Architect lived here 1764-1783
column16: Lancelot 'Capability' Brown was a pioneering landscape architect. He is today regarded as 'England's greatest gardener'. Brown began his career at Stowe, Buckinghamshire, under William Kent, one of the founders of the new English style of landscape garden. As a leading proponent of this style, families all over the country quickly sought after Brown. He was famously coined 'Capability' because he would often tell his clients that their estates had great 'capability' for improvement. It is estimated that Brown worked on over 170 gardens, and in 1764 he was appointed master gardener at Hampton Court Palace.

column14: Bert Hardy (1913-1995) Photographer Born and grew up in The Priory 'The man behind the camera'
column16: Bert Hardy was a documentary photographer known for his pioneering work for the liberal Picture Post magazine between 1941 and 1957. From humble working class origins in south London, Hardy had his first success when he photographed King George V and Queen Mary in a passing carriage and sold 200 prints of the best shot of the king. His first camera was a Leica 35mm, then an unconventional choice for photographers, but true to his belief that an expensive camera wasn't required for good pictures. He documented much of WWII, including the D-Day landings in 1944, and was one of the first photographers to enter the liberated Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Hardy is one of the most significant photographers of twentieth century Britain and in the history of press photography.

column14: Colen Campbell (1676-1729) Architect lived and died here
column16: Colen Campbell was a Scottish architect who is credited with founding the Georgian style of architecture. Initially training as a lawyer in Edinburgh, Campbell decided to move to London to become an architect. His highly influential publication 'Vitruvius Britannicus' (a catalogue of engravings of buildings by the likes of Inigo Jones and Sir Christopher Wren) popularised the neo-Palladian style that dominated early 18th century architecture in Britain and America. Campbell worked on such noted buildings as the Royal Academy in London, Stourhead in Wiltshire and his own London home, 76 Brook Street, in this new 'Georgian' style.

column6: Central School of Arts and Crafts, Southampton Row
column14: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) Architect and first principal of this school in 1896-1911
column16: William Richard Lethaby was an English architect and architectural historian whose ideas were highly influential on the late Arts and Crafts and early Modern movements in architecture, and also in the fields of conservation and art education. Born in Barnstaple, Lethaby was the son of a carver and gilder. He studied at the local art school and in architects' offices in Barnstaple and Derby, winning the Royal Institute of British Architects' Sloane Medallion in 1879, and the Pugin Studentship 1881. In London Lethaby founded the Central School of Arts and Crafts, now known as Central St. Martins, which is today considered to be one of the foremost institutes of the arts.

column14: Frank Matcham (1854-1920) Theatre Architect lived here 1895-1904
column16: Frank Matcham was a pioneering English architect who designed over 200 theatres throughout Britain between 1890-1915. In 1878 Matcham inherited the  architectural practice from where his most famous buildings were designed; these included the Hackney Empire, London Coliseum and the Victoria Palace theatre. His innovative steel cantilevers allowed balconies to be built without pillars, thereby improving sight lines for the audience, so making these buildings extremely popular with the theatre-going public.

column14: Here lived and died John Loughborough Pearson (1817-1897) and later Sir Edwin Landseer Lutyens (1869-1944) Architects
column16: Sir Edwin Landseer Lutyens was a pioneering English architect and designer. Through a long industrious career Lutyens contributed much to the architecture of the British nation and Commonwealth and is often referred to as 'the greatest English architect of all time'. He studied at what is now the Royal College of Art before starting his own practice in 1885. One of his most notable and famous designs is the Cenotaph in Whitehall. Lutyens was also commissioned to design New Delhi in India which was chosen to replace the seat of the British Indian government in 1912, and is today known as 'Lutyens Delhi'. This house was formerly also the residence of John Loughborough Peterson who was one of the foremost Gothic Revivalist architects of the late-Victorian era.

column14: Red House built in 1859-1860 by Philip Webb (1831-1915), architect for William Morris (1834-1896) poet and artist who lived here 1860-1864
column16: William Morris was an artist, writer, textile designer and utopian socialist. He was a key member of the influential Arts and Crafts Movement, and was closely associated with the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood of artists. He founded several companies dedicated to the production of decorative arts using traditional craft techniques; best known of these are Morris & Co. and the Kelmscott Press. Morris was also a writer of poetry, fiction and translations of ancient and medieval texts, and was a direct influence on J.R.R. Tolkien, who named some of his key characters after those in Morris's books. He lived at the Red House in Bexleyheath, which was designed by his friend Philip Webb, and is considered to be one of the most important buildings in the history of architecture.

column14: Sir Giles Gilbert Scott (1880-1960) Architect designed this house and lived here 1926-1960
column16: Sir Giles Gilbert Scott was an English architect, responsible for some of 20th century Britain's most iconic and famous buildings. His first major commission was the design of the Liverpool Anglican Cathedral when he was 21 years old; the project would last his lifetime. Scott also designed Battersea Power Station, which was completed in 1933. As well as significant work in architecture, he was also responsible for the design of the iconic red telephone box. Designed for the General Post Office after winning a competition, Scott's 'Kiosk No. 2' was notable for its unique domed roof and bright red finish, and was installed in every town and village in the country. Scott designed and lived in his house in Paddington from 1926 until his death in 1960.

column14: Luke Howard (1772-1864) Namer of clouds lived and died here
column16: Luke Howard was a British manufacturing chemist and an amateur meteorologist.  From 1801 he made comprehensive recordings of the weather and these inspired his writing 'Essay on the Modification of Clouds' in 1803. It was in this publication that Howard first proposed the three principal categories of clouds: cumulus, stratus and cirrus, as well as several sub-categories. His work was of significant impact on the study of weather and despite having no formal scientific education is known today as the 'father of meteorology'.  He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society on 8 March 1821.

column14: Robert Baden-Powell (1857-1941) Chief Scout of the World lived here
column16: Robert Baden-Powell is best known as the founder and Chief Scout of the Scout Movement. Baden-Powell served as lieutenant general in the British Army in India and Africa from 1876 until 1910, and in that time he formulated many of his ideas of the Scout movement. In 1907 he held the first Brownsea Island Scout camp- now seen as the beginning of scouting- and in 1908 published 'Scouting for Boys' which became the handbook for the movement. Baden-Powell was listed in the Nazis 'black book' which named key figures to be arrested if England was invaded by Germany during WWII: they considered scouting to be a spy organisation and Baden-Powell untrustworthy. Scouting continues to be popular around the world today.

column14: Sir Christopher Wren (1632-1723) Architect lived here
column16: Sir Christopher Wren was an English astronomer, mathematician and physicist, and one of the most acclaimed architects of all time. Wren is widely associated with the major rebuilding programme following the Great Fire of London in 1666, including St Paul's Cathedral and the lesser-known Monument, which was built to commemorate the fire and celebrate the rebuilding of the City. He was also responsible for the design of Greenwich Naval College, Kensington Palace, the library at Trinity College in Cambridge, and the south front of Hampton Court Palace. He was a founder of the Royal Society of which he was President from 1680 to 1682, and his scientific work was much admired by others, including Sir Isaac Newton.

column14: Alfred Waterhouse (1830-1905) Architect lived here
column16: Alfred Waterhouse was a British architect, particularly associated with Victorian Gothic Revival architecture. He designed a wide variety of buildings throughout the country but he is best known for designing the Natural History Museum in London, and Manchester Town Hall. Financially speaking, Waterhouse was probably the most successful of all Victorian architects. Though an expert in Neo-Gothic, Renaissance revival, and Romanesque revival forms, he never limited himself to a single architectural style. Waterhouse designed and lived in his house on New Cavendish Street, London.

column14: C.F.A. Voysey (1857-1941) Architect and Designer lived here
column16: CFA Voysey was an English architect and furnishings designer. Voysey began his career designing wallpaper and fabrics in the 1880s, his style much influenced by the Arts and Crafts Movement led by William Morris. Later he concentrated on architecture, and was unusual in his approach of designing every aspect of a house, including the furniture. He was concerned with form and function, and shunned ornamental complexities that were popular at the time. Such was Voysey's influence in the 1920s and 1930s he is often credited as being a pioneer of modern architecture, opting to eliminate detail and celebrate simplification of form, which is in contrast to the ornate decoration of his textile and wallpaper creations.

column14: Michael Ventris (1922-1956) Architect and Decipherer of Linear B script lived here
column16: Michael Ventris was an English architect and classical scholar who had a prodigious gift for languages. He is most famous for co-deciphering of Linear B, an early form of Greek; it pre dated the Greek alphabet by several centuries and had died out thousands of years before. In just his late twenties when he completed this feat, Ventris was awarded an OBE in 1955 in recognition of the significance of his work. He was to die only a year later in a car crash, aged 34.

column14: Thomas Smith Tait (1882-1954) Architect lived here
column16: Thomas Smith Tait was a prominent Scottish Modernist architect, who designed a number of Art Deco buildings. Having attended Glasgow School of Art, prestigious architects John Burnet & Sons recruited Tait in 1902 and he became a partner in 1918. It was at the practice that Tait produced his most notable works including the pylons for Sydney Harbour Bridge, St Andrew's House in Edinburgh and the later phases of Selfridge's, London. He also designed several modernist houses in St John's Wood as well as war memorials following the First World War. Tait lived in Gates House in Hampstead from 1928, which he tactfully modernised, fitting it out with Art Deco features.

column14: Sir Robert Smirke (1780-1867) Architect lived here
column16: Sir Robert Smirke was an English architect famous for his Greek Revivalist style. Like many architects of his time, Smirke was greatly influenced by the buildings and palaces he visited during his 'Grand Tour' of Europe during 1801-1805. The largest and best known of Smirke's buildings is the main block of London's British Museum, which he was invited to design in 1820. The main facade of the Museum and its great colonnade of 44 Greek iconic columns, are loosely based on those of Athena Polias at Priene-the ancient Greek city of Ionia, which he visited during his tour.

column14: Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828-1882) poet and painter and Algernon Charles Swinburne (1837-1909) poet lived here
column16: Dante Gabriel Rossetti was a British painter and poet, and co-founder of the celebrated Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood group of artists. His work was highly influential, particularly on his contemporaries William Morris and Edward Burne-Jones. After the death of his wife and muse Lizzie Siddal, Rossetti moved into this house where he lived for twenty years, surrounding himself with extravagant furnishings and exotic animals and birds, eventually becoming a recluse. Several of his paintings now belong to the Tate Gallery. For a time he lived here with his friend, the celebrated writer Algernon Charles Swinburne.

column14: Sir Robert Peel (1750-1830) Manufacturer and reformer and his son Sir Robert Peel (1788-1850) Prime Minister Founder of the Metropolitan Police lived here
column16: Sir Robert Peel was a British Conservative statesman who twice served as Prime Minister in the early-mid 19th Century. As home secretary, he formed the Metropolitan Police Force in 1829, which became the model of modern policing throughout the country. Police officers were affectionately nicknamed 'Bobbies' in his honour, and are often still called so today. Although unpopular at first, the constables proved successful at cutting crime. He lived here with his father Sir Robert Peel who was a British politician and industrialist, and one of the early textile manufacturers of the Industrial Revolution.

column14: Sir Robert Walpole (1676-1745) Prime Minister and his son Horace Walpole (1717-1797) Connoisseur and Man of Letters lived here
column16: Sir Robert Walpole was a British statesman who is generally regarded as the first prime minister of Great Britain. Such was his influence in the Cabinet and the politics of his day he was gifted 10 Downing Street by King George II; it remains the HQ of the British government today. His strategy of keeping Great Britain at peace in a historically unsettled period contributed greatly to its prosperity at the time. He lived here with his son Horace who is best known for his building of Strawberry Hill in Twickenham.

column14: Phyllis Pearsall (1906-1996) inventor of the London A to Z lived here
column16: Phyllis Pearsall was the creator of the A to Z map of London. Born in East Dulwich, she was widely travelled in Europe and made her living as a writer and painter, before returning to London. One evening in 1935 she became lost in the capital, and realised that her map, the most recent available, was published in 1919. She set about producing her own map, compiling 23,000 card alphabetical index of the streets. The first A to Z was published in 1936 and was an enormous success. Her company, Geographers' Map Company Ltd, is now the largest independent map publishers in the UK and its motto is 'On we go', given to them by Pearsall. She was awarded an MBE in 1989.

column14: Oscar Wilde (1854-1900) wit and dramatist lived here
column16: Oscar Wilde was an Irish writer and poet. He was one of the best-known figures of the late-Victorian era, famous for his plays, biting wit and flamboyant character. He wrote some of the best-loved and endearing plays and books such as  'The Importance of Being Earnest', and 'The Picture of Dorian Gray' and children's books 'The Selfish Giant' and 'The Happy Prince'. In 1895, at the height of his fame he attempted to bring a libel case against the father of his male lover, but which ultimately led to his own arrest and trial for gross indecency. He was imprisoned for two years' hard labour; upon his release he fled to Paris where he died destitute, in 1900.

column14: In this house occupied by Thomas Davies (1712-1785), bookseller, Dr. Samuel Johnson (1709-1784) first met James Boswell (1740-1795) in 1765
column16: Dr Samuel Johnson was a writer, poet and essayist who made lasting contributions to English literature. His work 'A Dictionary of the English Language' was published in 1755. It took him nine years to complete and was considered one of the greatest single achievements of scholarship. It was unsurpassed for 150 years, when the 'Oxford English Dictionary' was introduced. This house was occupied by Thomas Davies a bookseller and author, and it was he that first introduced Dr Johnson to James Boswell at this address. Boswell wrote 'The Life of Samuel Johnson' which is regarded as the greatest biography in the English language.

column14: James Glaisher (1809-1909) Astronomer, Meteorologist and pioneer of weather forecasting lived here
column16: James Glaisher was an English meteorologist and aeronaut, but is most famous as a pioneering balloonist. Between 1862-1866 Glaisher made numerous ascents to measure the atmosphere's humidity and temperature at its highest levels. His ascent on September 5th 1862 broke the world record for altitude, but he passed out at around 8,800 metres before a reading could be taken; estimates suggest it may have been as high as 10,900 metres (2,052 metres higher than Mt Everest). Glaisher was a founder member of the Meteorological Society, and worked at the Royal Greenwich Observatories from 1835-1869.

column14: Frank Pick (1878-1941) Pioneer of Good Design for London Transport lived here
column16: Frank Pick was a British transport administrator, who became one of the most important commissioners of art in Britain. Pick rose through the corporate ranks of the Underground Electric Railway Company of London (UERL) to become managing director in 1928. Early in his career he began work on developing a strong brand identity and visual style for which the London Underground is now famous. From standardisation of signage, to commissioning the Johnston 'Underground' typeface, Pick was responsible for creating some of the most iconic imagery of London's transport system, and in the history of graphic design.

column14: Amy Johnson (1903-1941) Aviator lived here
column16: Amy Johnson was a pioneering English aviator. She achieved worldwide recognition as a pilot in 1930, when she became the first woman to fly solo from Britain to Australia, in her biplane nicknamed Jason. Johnson married fellow aviator James Mollison and together they broke numerous long-distance flying records, including in 1933 being the first husband and wife team to fly non-stop from Britain to the USA. During WWII Johnson was recruited into the Air Transport Auxiliary, part of the Royal Air Force that was responsible for ferrying military aircraft across the country. On a routine flight on 5 January 1941, Johnson went off course in bad weather and was forced to bail out into the Thames Estuary; her body was never recovered.

column14: Charles Dickens (1812-1870) Novelist lived here
column16: Charles Dickens was an English writer who is regarded as the greatest novelist of the Victorian period; he was responsible for some of English literature's most iconic stories and characters. Thrust into poverty at an early age, Dickens drew much inspiration for his novels 'Great Expectations' and 'David Copperfield' from the appalling conditions he experienced working in a factory as a boy. His work has never been out of print and his novel 'A Christmas Carol' has sold over 200 million copies since its publication in 1859. Dickens and his family lived at 48 Doughty Street from 1837 to 1839, and it was here that his sister-in-law Mary died in his arms after a brief illness; his memories of her inspired several characters in his novels, notably Little Nell in 'The Old Curiosity Shop'.

column14: Charles Rolls (1877-1910) Pioneer of Motoring and Aviation worked here 1905-1910
column16: Charles Rolls was a pioneer of motoring and aviation technologies. As a young man Rolls studied mechanical and applied science, and became an early motoring enthusiast, travelling to Paris to buy his first car, a Peugeot. In 1903, he founded C.S. Rolls & Co, in Fulham, one of the first car dealerships in Britain, but a meeting in 1904 with manufacturer Charles Royce was the start of the now infamous partnership; the result was one of the worlds best-known car brands, the Rolls-Royce. Rolls was also a pioneer aviator and balloonist, and would fly his plane at spectacular aeronautical displays, but tragically died in a flying accident at one such event, aged just 32.

column14: Lady Violet Bonham Carter, Baroness Asquith of Yarnbury (1887-1969) Politician and writer lived here
column16: As the daughter of British Prime Minister H.H. Asquith, Lady Violet Bonham Carter grew up surrounded by politics. She was also a keen writer and diarist, and involved in arts and literature of her time. In her adult life Bonham Carter became an active Liberal politician at a time when it was uncommon for women to be in such frontline political roles; she was also a great friend of Winston Churchill. Bonham Carter recognised early on the dangers of rising European fascism, and was a key member of several anti-fascist groups, as such she was listed in the Nazis' so-called  'Black Book'. She is the grandmother of British actress Helena Bonham Carter.

column14: Sam Wanamaker (1919-1993) Visionary who recreated Shakespeare's Globe
column16: Sam Wanamaker was an American actor and film director, and is credited as being the key person behind the recreation of Shakespeare's Globe Theatre on Bankside. Wanamaker settled in England in 1952 after discovering that he was on the 'Hollywood blacklist', largely due to his public support for others on the list. Wanamaker had a lifelong love of Shakespeare, acting in several productions and was director of the New Shakespeare Theatre in Liverpool. On an early visit to London in 1949 he had sought evidence of the site of original theatre, and in 1970 he founded the Shakespeare Globe Trust to see it rebuilt, and this became his 'great obsession'. He died just 4 years before the project was completed and the theatre finally re-opened to the public.

column14: Sir Charles Eastlake (1793-1865) Painter and first director of the National Gallery lived here
column16: Sir Charles Lock Eastlake was a skilled historical painter, learning under Benjamin Haydon, and was later a student of the Royal Academy. The sale of an early painting of Napoleon allowed him to travel to study the old masters; these travels over many years were a great influence on his painting and his theories of art. Eastlake became keeper of the National Gallery in 1843 and director in 1855; he spent many summers abroad, acquiring works for the gallery, many of which can still be seen hanging in the public galleries. His purchases were of great significance and enabled the gallery to rival the other great art institutions of the world, such as the Louvre in Paris. Eastlake also set groundbreaking standards for conservation, management, and hanging of pictures, which are still followed today.
